title: The heart of Midlothian;
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: once rushed on Balderstone's mind, that the Lord of Ravenswood  should perish on the Kelpie's slow, which lay half-way betwixt the Tower and the links, or sand knolls, to the northward  of Wolf's Hope.

title: The heart of Midlothian;
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "And you will go, then ?" said Caleb, loosening hishoxf' upon the Master's cloak, and changing his didactics into a pathetic and mournful tone — " and you tvill go, for a' I have told you about the prophecy, and the dead bride, and the Kelpie's quicksand ? Aweel ! a wilful man maun hae his way : he that will to Cupar maun to Cupar.

title: The heart of Midlothian;
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "Well, Caleb," said the Master, "•'! give jou the best possible credit for your good advice on this occasion ; but as I do not go to Raveuswood to seek a bride, dead or alive, I hope I shall choose a better stable for my horse than the Kelpie's quicksand, and especially as I have always had a particular dread of it since the patrol of dragoons were lost there ten years since.

title: The heart of Midlothian;
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: " I know the Kelpie's slow well enough," said the Master ; " I suppose, at least, you mean the quicksand betwixt this tower and Wolf's Hope ; but why any man in his senses should stable a steed there "

title: The heart of Midlothian;
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: " ' When the last Laird of Ravenswood to Ravenswood shall ride And woo a dead maiden to be his bride, He shall stable his steed in the Kelpie's slow, And his name shall be lost f orevermoe ! ' "

title: The laird of Norlaw :
author: Oliphant
snippet: She ran along up the icy, chilly road, with the night-wind cutting her delicate little ears, and her rapid footsteps sliding upon the knots of roots in the path, straight up to that height where the Kelpie trickled, and the last red cloud melted into grey behind the trees.

title: The laird of Norlaw :
author: Oliphant
snippet: The Kelpie itself was scarcely recognizable in the torpid and tiny stream which trickled down its little ravine — only the sharp sound of its monotone in the tingling air made you aware of its vicinity ; and frozen Tyne no longer added his

title: The laird of Norlaw :
author: Oliphant
snippet: Malice and curiosity together did more to keep her warm than the cloak and fur tippet, yet she almost repented when she found herself among the frozen, snow-sprinkled trees, with the saint tinkle of the Kelpie striking sharp, yet drowsy, like a little stream of metal through the frost-bound stillness, and no one visible on the path, where now and then her foot slid upon a treacherous bit of ice, inlaid in the hard brown soil.

title: The laird of Norlaw :
author: Oliphant
snippet: — and with a glance, and a shrug and a shiver at the frosty languor of the diminished Kelpie, drew his cloak close round him, and turned towards the house, whither, Joanna eagerly, and Desire* with great reluctance and annoyance,  the girls were constrained to follow.

title: The laird of Norlaw :
author: Oliphant
snippet: The Kelpie fell scantily, with a drowsing tinkle over its little ravine, reduced to the slenderest thread, while all the branches near it were hung with mocking icicles.

title: The laird of Norlaw :
author: Oliphant
snippet: " She thought she knew the Kelpie, did she ? — hum ! and her mother is a Scotchwoman  — for that matter, so is yours.

title: The laird of Norlaw :
author: Oliphant
snippet: "And that is all because Desiree thinks she must have heard her mamma speak of the Kelpie waterfall," said Joanna ; " because she thought she knew it as soon as she saw it — that is all ! — did you ever hear the like, papa ? "

title: The laird of Norlaw :
author: Oliphant
snippet: triumph — ^^ she took quite a fancy to Kirkbride,  when she came first, and was sure she had heard of the Kelpie waterfall.

title: The laird of Norlaw.
author: Oliphant
snippet: But that whole silent day passed over him unenlightened ; lie got through the inevitable meals he could scarcely tell how replied" or did not reply to his mother s remarks, which he scarcely noticed were spoken at, and not to him, wandered out in the afternoon to Tyneside and the Kelpie, without finding any one there and finally, with a pang of almost unbearable rebellion, submitted to the night and sleep which he could not avoid.

title: The laird of Norlaw.
author: Oliphant
snippet: No ; there is no love-tale to tell but that which has been told already ; all those preliminaries are over ; the Kelpie saw them pledge their faith to each other, while there still were but a sprinkling of spring leaves on those trees of June.

title: The laird of Norlaw.
author: Oliphant

title: The laird of Norlaw.
author: Oliphant
snippet: The Tyne ran softly beneath his banks, the Kelpie rushed foam ing white down its little ravine, and all the cool burns from among the trees dropped down into Tyne with a sound like silver bells.

title: The laird of Norlaw.
author: Oliphant
snippet: What Cosmo told Madame Roche months after, Madame Roche s little daughter knew on that winter night by the Kelpie, when the tale of Aunt Jean, and all its confirming circumstances, stung her poor little heart with its first consciousness of falsehood and so cial treachery.

title: The laird of Norlaw.

title: The laird of Norlaw.
author: Oliphant
snippet: The Kelpie itself was scarcely recogniz able in the torpid and tiny stream which trickled down its little ravine ; only the sharp sound of its monotone in the tingling air made you aware of its vicinity ; and frozen Tyne no longer added his voice to make the silence musical.

title: The laird of Norlaw.
author: Oliphant
snippet: Malice and curiosity together did more to keep her warm than the cloak and fur tippet, yet she almost re pented when she found herself among the frozen, snow- sprinkled trees, with the saint tinkle of the Kelpie striking sharp, yet drowsy, like a little stream of metal through the frost-bound stillness, and no one visible on the path, where now and then her foot slid upon a treacherous bit of ice, in laid in the hard brown soil.

title: The laird of Norlaw.
author: Oliphant
snippet: He begged to know how they could find any pleasure out of doors in this ferocious climate on such a clay and with a glance, and a shrug and a shiver at the frosty languor of the diminished Kelpie, drew his cloak close round him, and turned towards the house, whither, Joanna eagerly, and Desiree with great reluctance and annoyance, the girls were constrained to follow.

title: The Edinburgh tales.
author: Johnstone, C. I.
snippet: " It was odd enough, though, my leddy, that that same imp of the deil, Kelpie the pony and it's said among their lying freits that the sire of that mettle race was the Water-Kelpie should have died just seven days after he, unchancy brute, threw your leddyship ; and that the bairn ye made of, and kissed and praised and that was an honour! should so soon thereafter have dreed its wierd, misdeedy brat."
